Vol.. VII.

\Y 21, 1903.

No. 15.

A TREATISE ON THE COW-PUNCHER.
He is likely idle,
ex), I NITER is an empty season to the "cow-puncher.
though there is a chance that, as one out of twenty, he is retained to
"ride fence" or " ride bog holes," in the first case to patrol the barbwire and repair gaps that might allow flow from one pasture to another, and in
the second to haul forth from at least one certainty of death the many weakened
cattle that get mired. For the ranch-owner winter is such a hazard that he would
hold his breath through it if the period of danger were a trifle shorter. Ravens
Prospect about the prairie ; there are raw skins hung on the fences; and rumors
come from further on the plains that the "I.Ialf-circle W's- have lost two thousand head.
The popular •mood lightens when Spring comes in, nimbly as always ; and,
after a thorough rain with predictions that "there'll be grass in two weeks," the
men begin to gather to the ranch headquarters. They are perhaps a fortnight
ahead of the least move to work, yet they are welcome to unroll their bedding in
the "dive," to eat of the.beef and stewed prunes in the "chuck-house," and so to
wait till what time they may be taken under wages again.
Among them are many "sweaters," — crude boys, on a first essay, whose
capital in life is the remnants of a saddle and a willingness to ride bronchos.
ri;very one waits in ignorance, because the manager is as a rule hostile to inquiries,
hut at last a dav is realized on which the punchers of last year get their places
anew and perhaps tionie of the "sweaters" cast off that name ; and on the next
morning the "outfit" starts for the pasture ;—a line of horsemen, followed cumbrously by a wagon piled high with bedding and tooled by the cook.
On the Stirrup Ranch as on others, the horses are to be got first,—the three
or four hundred animals turned out for the winter,—and to that end the outfit,
after a while of slow travel, makes camp upon the mesquite-covered prairie at the
foot of the great steppe that is the Plains. The gather is accomplished in sections, and each day possesses the same round of active work. In the early hours
the view is quiet as the men scatter to their places in a loose circle that may hold
within it thirty square miles ; then all about in the green of the mesquite one sees
far off brown and white motes in mid-career with a variegated speck close behind and a second, swift as a centaur, closing in from another quarter; then
the motes resolve themselves into horses and the specks into mounted men ; and
Perhaps ten minutes after the ground in front of one is full of the tiinnilt of hoofs
and of pursuers and pursued until it settles with a restive bunch of horses and
pickets round about you. The cow-boys take fresh mounts from those cap-

tured ; and as they' rope for some particular head among so many it is not unusual
. favorite of last year,---'A1 Bald" it may be or "Diamond
that they miss the
joe,"—and catch a bronch' which four men at the end of the rope must strain
to hold till the running noose has "choked him down." Old favorites too rebel
at first of the saddle, and it is under such circumstances that high art in "bucking"
is most evident, with the rider in that contorted bend which the stranger never
understands to be involuntary till he himself has been "busted" by a broncho.
A proportion of the horses ignore the gregarious instinct and make escape to be
outlaws ; yet after a week the outfit can return to the ranch-house with a docile
quarter of a mile of horses driven before.
At the ranch there is a stir with friction over the choice of mounts. Each
man has the dozen that served him last year yet wishes as many more ; and
discussion of hocks and withers and stifle-joints is hot, until with the allotment
under charge of the "horse-wrangler" the outfit puts forth afresh, this time to
work with the cattle.
The grass rises ankle-deep by now on the Stirrup lands, and even where the
prairie-soil shows through are great white and lemon primroses and mats of
purple verbena. What part of the pasture lies on the Plains has still a rather
hare sward ; and when one ascends the "Cap-Rock,"—a hundred feet of rough,
colored slope, which like the moraine to a glacier, is an abrupt border along the
foot of the wide-spread plateau,--.--one finds an expanse of earth and sky, elementary as an ocean view, but with a somber fixedness that the ocean has not,
with perhaps an uneasy antelope or two in the distance, a wire fence that goes
rapidly off into perspective, and quivering lines of heat that for some reason
magnify the far-off herd grotesquely and give its members unsteady, stilt-like legs.
Each morning the outfit makes a drive that ends in a round-up. The drive,
though slower, is of a plan with that for horses. 1 ly the time the sun has got
to its strength the cattle have been started from the grazing and appear in troops
that center on an open level in the mesquites. If the drive be large a van-guard
of baby calves will clog proceedings, and some must he carried over the pommel
of the saddle, and some stirred with the foot, when they flop down and relapse
instantly into sleep, as they will in spite of circumstances that should cause them
anxiety, and some even be left with a mother to stand over them. Before noon
a couple of acres of cattle are assembled ; a couple of acres of tossed horns and
crowded brown backs ; a couple of acres that bleat and bawl like a brass band
in its preliminaries ; and that eddy ,round and round. The men change horses,—
they are always changing horses at the least moment of rest,—and the more
arduous "cutting out" begins, to obtain the yearlings at this season. It is very
like polo:—dust, with horses that dodge in the midst of the dust, only in this instance instead of the ball, a yearling, fond of his parent, is to be separated from
her, and out of the press and coerced to the bunch of his fellows a hundred yards
off. As time goes the cattle circle more restlessly and are harder to "hold," the
dust rises and blows, and the bellowing and moos become loudly incessant ; until
second outfit interlocks with that so far
the final yearling is "chousted out.
followed, with which the yearlings must go perforce off to exile till they arc

weaned; so labor for the first gang has its finish for the day. There is a steeplechav to where dinner waits with the wagon at sonic near-by tank of water.
hater comes a move to fresh territory, but always an hour or two is on hand at
the cool end of the afternoon, through which one can wash saddle-blankets or
bridle a "quirt," lie in laziness, or,—if conditions ask for it,—stretch "tepees"
against the rain.
Thus till the fall, even till December, cow-boys punch cattle. (hi the Stirnip's land, with its 40,000 head, work exists till late. In Spring the yearlings
must be weaned, then the brand is put on calves,—breathless business it is for
the fellow who must wind arms about fifty in succession as they bound at the
end of the rope, and throw them (breathless too, for the calves),—and at all
times special grades are to be separated for market. Through these processes
runs the organization into herd and round-up and cut. "Stray men" are sent
with a string of horses and a pack of quilts to follow the round-ups of the
"Lazy L's "( ) nearby and claim property that has got past the barb-wire;
and sometimes sonic one is called upon to find a trail to the rail-road,—for now
what with fences a herd may not be brought straight by compass. Once or
twice a season the outfit must "go on the trail," when, indeed, it pays for idleness
with a routine which insists that each man shall herd and press on while it is
light and stand a watch in the darkness, and even guard through the night if the
cattle are anxious. Year-long convoys from Texas to Montana or even lower
Canada, without help of the railroad, are undertaken, but conditions against these
gain in. stringency.
The cow-boy draws from $25 to $-10 each month for his irregular performance, whereas a farm-hand of the same region bends his back so long as
he is awake, yet may not expect more than $16 in a similar length of time ; that
shows nearly the ratio of skill in the employments. Skill insures life in the cowboy's case as more spectacularly in the steeple-jack's. The cow-boy is often
under discomfort, of weather, of lone vigil, of isolation ; his future is unstable,
except in most cases for a certainty that he will be laid off without wages during
the bitter stretch of the year. Altogether one cannot judge him overpaid.
The type of man may almost be deduced from the conditions given,—had
it not been often depicted with more gusto than discretion. Young blood finds
the life good and in many instances grows to be old blood while the charm of it
still hangs in the veins. One sees many middle-aged and stout cow-boys. Change
has broken not a few traits of the country ; the six-shooter is no longer a habit,
under the fines that now hedge about its possession ; and shortly as time goes, the
great free-handed ranches will disintegrate into small careful stock-farms. The
old-timers, lavish in their dealings with the world, find in each year a load of
disappointment, but a reasonable half of the punchers, hacked by youth and
steadied by ambition, have an eve to their doubtful prospects, and are at earnest
to make a "stake" in cattle. Indeed nowadays the "Great Staked Plains," as a
R. '00,
name, has attained to much truth,

THE AMERICAN STATE.
F,DrrED

BY PROFESSOR W. W.

wILLouGit By.

The Century Company, of New York, is to publish a series of volumes under
the general title Of "The American State," which is to be edited by Dr. W. W.
Willoughby, Associate Professor of Political Science. The aim of the series is
to describe comprehensively the manner in which the governmental agencies of
the American State, Federal, Commonwealth, and Local are now organized and
administered. While the volumes shall be descriptive of actual conditions, incidentally they will aim to suggest the various constitutional and administrative
problems that exist, and make manifest the essential considerations involved in
their settlement.
The series will consist of eight volumes, as follows: The American Constitutional System; American Legislatures and Legislative M ethods ; The American
Executive and Executive Methods ; TheAmerican Judicial System ; Territories
and Colonies ; Local Government in the United States ; City Government in the
United States; and Political Party Machinery.
It will be observed, that as distinguished from many so-called "series" or
"libraries," this set of volumes will constitute a logical wbole, that is, will be encyclopedic as regards the special field covered. Each volume, though complete
in itself will have its proper place with special reference to that fact.
The first volume of the series, "The American Constitutional System," the
aim of which will be to furnish a general introduction to a study of the constitutional system of the American State, is to be prepared by Dr. Willoughby, who
expects to publish his book before the end of the year. Four of the remaining
volumes have already been provided for, and the editor hopes to have the entire
series published by the end of 1904.

NEW EDITOR OF JUVENAL.
The edition of the satires of Juvenal, upon which Dr. H. L. Wilson has
been at work for several years, is to be issued from the press early in June.
The book will consist of about 400 pages, and will contain a discussion of
Roman satire, the life of Juvenal, Juverial's style and place in literature, a history
of the text and a bibliography. Besides this there will be a complete text of the
author, including the recently discovered Bodleian fragments, the commentaries
and the index.
The book is not only intended for undergraduate students, but also offers to
teachers and advanced students assistance for a more thorough study of the satires
and information as to the progress made in the interpretation of this author
during the past ten years,

THE

NEWS LETTER.

THE HULLABALOO CLUB FEED.
ATURDAY night last, a feed was given in the Trophy Room by the "Hullabaloo" Club to the Junior Class. The occasion was celebrated by several impromptu "'stunts" in the cage, the most interesting being hurdle
races, participated in by self-constituted sprinters, who, though more or less
stained by their race, were overshadowed by another and blacker race, two
chocolate representatives who indulged in a boxing bout. Jim "also ran" upon
the scene to play the rubber, aml with a towel, circumscribed the dark circles
under the eyes of the sluggers and smoothed their newly evoked facial ripples.
Thus seeing the race problem summarily disposed of, both classes retired
to the Trophy Room, where they regaled themselves with tempting edibles,
liquidating their debts to the inner man with time draughts on their own high
spirits.
Secretary Addison announced from the bench that the following men had
been selected to compose the Board of Governors of the Club for the ensuing
year: Messrs. Fuerbring-er, Erlanger, Stollenwerck, ll'earre, Buckler, Wayson,
Hawkins, Louis, Branch and Foster.
The Hullabaloo Club was organized by the Class of 1903 for the purpose
of promoting good-fellowship among its members. Its constitution, if conscientiously adhered to, will no doubt be the means of bringing the men closer together socially, and will do much towards fostering good will and disproving
the no college life idea at Hopkins.
The object of the organizers of the Club was to eliminate all politics from
it, there being no presidential office to be filled, the supervision of the business
details being vested in the Baord, assisted hy a Secretary and a Treasurer.
If the requite amount of interest to render the organization successful is
shown, the Board of Governors may decide to ask the lower classes to identify
themselves with the Club, and thus make it an undergraduate and not a class
organization.
The Seniors are invited to attend the Field Night to be given by the Hopkins Club on Saturday, May 1,3rd. Dr. Welch will give a short talk, and refreshments will be served later.
On last Thursday, the class in Minor Botany, under the charge of Dr. Barton and I\1 r. Gudger, took a trip to Mt. Washington for the purpose of studying
the flora.
The University musical clubs made their last appearance of the year at the
concert for the benefit of the Lawrence House Mission, given in conjunction with
the Woman's College Musical Clubs on the night of May 9th. The attendance
was large, and a considerable sum was turned over to the mission.
A committee from the Junior Class is making arrangements for a feed and a
smoker at the close of the examinations.
The minor geology class made a trip to the Luray Caves last week under the
charge of Dr. Shattuck. They left Friday afternoon and returned Sundav morning. Those who went were Nelson, Winternitz, Riley and Bamberger.

HE number of books that are being published by University men is worthy
of more than passing notice. Scarcely an issue of ME NEWS-LETTER
appears that does not contain an account of new books by Hopkins professors or alumni. This number conains two important announcements, one of the
new edition of Juvenal, by Dr. Harry L. Wilson, and the other of the series, The
American State, which is to be edited by Dr. W. W. Willoughby. Some time ago
Tliv, NEws-LnuR contained a note to the effect that Prof. Wilson was preparing
a new edition of Juvenal, but nothing definite was stated. Now, however, we are
able to speak more of this book, which has been eagerly awaited by scholars, and
which bids fair to fulfil all that is expected of it. We are informed by competent
authority that Dr. Wilson's work is the most thorough edition of the Latin
Satirist ever published in this country, and will probably at once become the
authority. The series of the American State, to be edited by Dr. Willoughby,
will be one of the most important contributions to Political Science that has been
issued for some time. While all the volumes have not yet been assigned to
writers, it is probably that a majority of them will be written by Hopkins men,
since the part they have taken in advanced economic work is great. The publication of these books indicates that the spirit of creative intellectuality at the 'University is as vigorous as ever.

HE 1903 "Hullabaloo," of which the first edition, so to speak, was issued
. last Monday, is, in many respects, the best year-book which has been
brought out since the introduction of this time-honored custom of Hopkins
undergraduate life. The approval shown by every one who has bought a copy is
the best proof of the fact that the book is up to the expectations of the most
critical. The neatness and fullness of the book, and the almost total absence of
the ordinary typographical errors, indicate the long and careful work of a comtetent board of editors.
The features which seem to arouse the most interest and cause the most
laughter, are the "stunts" and the "grinds" on members of the Senior class. The
"Hullabaloo Intelligence Office" could not be improved upon. The virtues and
vices of each man are taken off in an extremely outspoken way. The class
opinions are original, interesting and comprehensive. The result of the class vote
on the handsomest man doubtless caused much sorrow.
The pictures are excellent. The color drawing is particularly dainty and
They,
attractive. The drawings by prominent artists speak for themselves.
however, have the disadvantage that the .woman experienced when she carried a
new Venus de Milo into her slightly shabby parlor. Everything else looked
small in comparison, even things which, not subjected to such invidious parallels,
would stand well on their own smaller merits in their own smaller way. This
gives the book a species of unevenness, which, however, easily gives away to
fascination when we take any detail by itself.
The various departments of the l Tniversity are arranged in a pleasing and
thorough manner, particularly "\thletics. The "Songs of johns Hopkins" are
also a good point about the book.
In conclusion, the following criticism might, perhaps, be made. The 1903
"Hullabaloo" is hardly, as the editors jokingly claim, "truly representative of
the l'niversity," as it has to do wholly with the Senior class. We venture this
less as a criticism than as a suggestion to future "Hullabaloos."

HE next issue of Tin.: Nrows-I,ImER, the last for the academic year, willl be
the usual commencement number. In a compact form it will aim to give
a summary of what the i Tniversity students have done during the past
Year. There will be pictures of the different athletic teams, and reviews of the
work done by them during the year will be given by their respective captains.
In order that all departments may be represented, there will be photographs of
THE NEws-LwrTER and "Hullabaloo" boards, together with an account of these
publications and suggestions for the future, by one who has been prominent in
both. What the members of 1903 have done 'in the University, Athletic and
Class affairs during their college days, together with their plans for the future,
and portraits of the more prominent men will be one of the features.

Dr. W. S. Thayer formally opened the annual session of the American
Medical Association, held in New Orleans. Dr. Welch read a paper on "Sources
and. Manner of Infection of Typhoid Fever. He further introduced a resolution,
which was carried, that the Association urge President Roosevelt to name a reputable medical man on the isthmian Canal Commission, in view of the dangers
arising from the unsanitary region through which the canal will be cut.
Dr. William H. Tolman, director of the American Institute of Social Service,
lectured in McCoy Hall on ''The Problem of the City Child." The lecture was
in the interest of the Lawrence House, and was illustrated with many lantern
slides.
Dean Edward H. Griffin will .deliver the address to the graduating class of
the Maryland College for Women, Lutherville, on Tuesday, June 2.
Dr. John M. Vincent attended the anniversary exercises of Oberlin College,
held last week.
Dr. Remsen has been appointed a member of the committee to consider
means of preserving the Declaration of Independence, which is fading to such an
extent that the names of the signers are scarcely discernible.
Mr. Henry J. Bowdoin, '81, has been elected one of the trustees of the
University. After graduating here, Mr. Bowdoin studied law. He is the first
graduate of the University to be elected a trustee.
Dr. J. H. Hollander delivered an address on "Socialism," before the Baltimore Typographical l'nion, No. 12, at Hazazer's Hall, on the 10th. A discussion followed, in which Drs. Gould and :Franklin took an active part.
President Remsen took a prominent part in the dedication exercises at Tome
Institute. Other Hopkins men in attendance were Dean Griffin and Dr. B. C.
Steiner.
Dr. Jacob H...Hollander, who had been asked to go as a special United States
Commissioner to the Philippines for the purpose of supervising the establishment
of the gold-standard currency system there, has declined the appointment on
account of press of other work.
Mr. J. H. Moore, a graduate student in physics, has accepted the position
of observer in the Lick Observatory. The place has just been vacated by Dr.
Herbert M. Reese, a former Hopkins man.

THE NEWS LETTER.

9

President-Emeritus Gilman and Dr. W. H. Welch are interested in the movement to have a monument erected to the memory of the late Major Walter Reed.
At the annual meeting of the managing committee of the American School
in Rome, which is maintained by the Archaeological Institute of America, with
the co-operation of several American universities, Dr. Harry I,. Wilson was appointed professor in Latin for the year 1905-06. It will be remembered . that
.Professor Mintor Warren, formerly of the University, was sent to Rome as the
director of the American School in 1896.
A large party of members of the graduate department of biology will spend
the summer months in special research work at the Marine Biological Laboratory at Beaufort, N. C. Among them are Messrs. D. H. Tennent, R. P. Cowles,
and Samuel Rittenhouse. Mr. Olin F. Shreeve, who is at present in Jamaica,
with Dr. Johnson, of the Ilotanical department of the University, will also join
the party on his return. Mr. S. H. Derickson, another member of the department, will accompany the expedition of the Geographical Society of Baltimore,
which will leave for the Bahamas on J tine Gth. He will have charge of the biological work of the expedition. The biological laboratory at Beaufort, which is
conducted under the management of the United States Fish Commission, will

LACROSSE.

J. H. U., 3—Crescents, 10.
0N May 9th, before several thousand spectators, the Hopkins lacrosse team
suffered its first defeat of the season in the game against the Crescent
Athletic Club, of Brooklyn, the score being 10 to 3. The ,game was one
of the nu.)st scientific exhibitions of lacrosse ever seen in Baltimore ; but most of
the science was on the side of the visitors. The 'Varsity did not seem to play up
to its usual standard, for its work appeared tame in comparison with that of its
opponents, who played the real Canadian game. It was not poor playing, however, that lost for the 1.Tniversity, but superior playing by the Crescents. In
every point of the game Hopkins was clearly outclassed. The weight of the
Crescent players averaged far more than that of the Hopkins men, and their
body checking was in consequence something terrible.
The passing of the
champions was faultless, and it was only through the fastest kind of work on
the part of the defense that plays were broken up. The defeat, however, is by
no means an inglorious one, for the victors are all star players. They are the
pick of some of the best teams in the country, and have been playing lacrosse
for years; therefore it was expected that they would be victorious over the 'Varsity.
Hopkins defense certainly played a fine article of lacrosse at times, and if
they could have struck their gait sooner, the Crescents could not have rolled up
ten goals. The body checking of Tough was very effective all through the game
in breaking up plays, and from the latter part of the first half to the close of the
game, Bland( also brought in his weight for some splendid work. On the Hopkins attack, Abercrombie did by far the best work. This is the first game in
which he has been allowed to play during this year, owing to the four-year-limit
rule, and the great player •hears comparison with any on either team. If the
other attack men had some of the confidence with which he plays, Hopkins would
have made more goals.
Hopkins got the ball at the start, and passed it down toward the net. Near
the posts Liffton obtained the ball, then passed it to Simpson, who threw to
Curry, who in turn had almost a clear field, as the defense was too late in covering up, and he threw the first goal within a minute from the time the game
commenced. Again the ball went rapidly down to Hopkins territory, and an

THE NEWS LETTER..
attempt was made at goal, but Schmeisser blocked it with his body. In the scrimmage that followed, Lindsay obtained the ball and shot the second goal. Within
the next twenty minutes some fine playing was seen. The 'Varsity had apparently recovered from its nervous spell and now settled down to business. The
ball was passed to Curry, who made a pretty run through his opponents right
up to the post. Just as he was about to shoot, Blanck struck him with his body,
and knocked the ball out of his stick. The ball was thrown down the field to
Rosenheim, who passed to Bird, and by Bird to Matthai. Matthai threw it to
Putts, who attempted goal. Everyone thought a goal was sure, but their hopes
were dashed to the ground when Dr. Rose made a fine stop. For some time the
ball was kept near the Crescents' goal. The•game was now on in earnest. Hopkins worked hard to put the sphere between the posts, and several attempts were
made. The ball passed from side to side. Several times P. Straus was called
upon to make difficult stops, and each, time he was right there.
It was during this playing that the Hopkins players scored their first goal.
Bird got the ball and passed to Rosenheim, who threw to liernheini. Beruheim
dodged his opponents and placed the ball in the net. About three minutes later
Crescent increased her lead to three. After some more see-saw playing, the
half ended with the ball near Hopkins' goal.
In the first part of the second half, Crescent took Hopkins' nerve completely,
by making six goals, each about two minutes apart. After this the locals commenced to cover up more, and the result was a decided brace. From the time
Crescent made her ninth goal to the close, Hopkins played by far the best of
any time during the game. The whole attack got together and kept the ball most
of the time in Crescent territory. Such playing could not fail to bring its reward, and Hopkins scored two more goals to Crescent's one. The game ended
with the ball in the middle of the field.
The Hopkins line-up was: Putts, in-home ; Bernheim, out-home ; Rosenheim,
first attack ; Abercrombie, second attack ; Bird, third attack ; Matthai, center ;
Tough, third defense ; Custis, second defense ; H. Straus, (captain) first defense ;
Ilanck, cover point ; Schmeisser, point ; P. Straus, goal.

DUAL MEET WITH VIRGINIA.

Ill-i', season of the track and field team practically closed on Thursday, May
7th, when in the presence of a large crowd of faithful rooters, the Hopkins squad gained a decided victory over the athletes from the University
of Virginia. This meet made a sort of "garrison" finish, forming a fitting climax
to a successful season's work. In the eleven events, Hopkins won 8 firsts and
5 seconds, thus getting 55 points, as against the 33 of Virginia. It looked at first
as if everything was coming our way, but later Virginia got together and suc-

t

THE NEWS LETTER.

13

ceeded in making their presence felt. Disregarding results as shown by the summary,. the visitors need feel in no way dissatisfied with their performance; it was
simply a case of "when Greek meets Greek," in which Hopkins proved to be the
better Gre,ek ; a .case of a good man losing to a better one in a hard struggle.
Aside from this meet being peculiarly satisfactory to Hopkins enthusiasts,
it was of much interest from a purely athletic point of view, in that State records
were broken so often that the novelty of it was beginning to wear off. First
individual honors were carried off by H. K. Tootle, who won both the 100 yard
and the 220 yard dashes, in each case lowering the State records of 10 1-5 and
23 seconds respectively, by covering the distances in 10 and 22 flat. The world's
records are 9 3-5 seconds for the 100 yards, held by Arthur F. Duffy, and 21 1-5
seconds for the 220 yards, held by B. J. Wefers. J. A. Freese established records
for the 120 yard high hurdle and 220 yard low hurdle, his time being 17 2-5 and
27 seconds respectively. In the quarter mile run, Captain Shelton, of Virginia,
lowered the State record of 51 2-5 seconds, formerly held by England, to 51 1-5
seconds. Besides these, the pole vault was won quite handily by T. W. Emig,
who, although entered before in several indoor events, had never specially distinguished himself. His victory came quite as a welcome surprise, and shows talent
that has previously been too little regarded. After winning with a jump of 9
feet, 11 1-4 inches, Emig endeavored to break the State record of 10 feet, 1 inch,
and (lid successfully clear the bar at 10 feet, 2 1-1 inches, but his pole afterward
knocked the bar down.
The good work for Hopkins began with the 1.00 yard dash and continued with
few interruptions until the end. All four (lashes were hotly contested, but ,Hopkins won out in each, through the instrumentality of Tootle and Freese. In the
1,10 yard run, Shelton and Bass, of Virginia, had the lead till near the finish.
when Captain Hoffman, by a beautiful sprint, passed Bass and ended in second
place. The surprise of the afternoon, however, came in the mile run. Grant,
of Virginia, gave out about. GOO yards from the tape, while Tyree lacked about
half that distance of finishing. The race then narrowed down to the two freshmen, Morse and ,Campbell, was a contest to decide to whom the "H" was to be
awarded. With not more than a foot separating them, Morse crossed the tape in
the lead. Hopkins clearly showed her superority in the dashes and in the long
distance run of one •mile, but had to give the palm to Virginia for the distances
of 440 and 880 yards. The summary of events was as follows:

Y. M. C. A. NOTES

The Association at the University of Illinois has been doing- splendid work
this )'ear. They have had 355 men enrolled in voluntary Bible Classes, and a
band of 21 volunteers for Foreign Missionary service, of whom 12 have been enrolled since the close of last college year.
The May Intercollegian publishes an interesting list of names of 211 student
volunteers who have sailed for Foreign Missionary work since March, 1902.
It is interesting to note that the largest number is to China, where they are needed
to take the places of those killed during the Boxer uprising.
The prospect for a strong and interesting conference at Northfield this summer, June 20th to July 5th, is very good. The names and number of speakers
is very strong and one of the latest additions is that of Rev. R. j. Campbell, of
the City Temple, London, England. One promised improvement in camp is a
"rustic lodge," with reading room. Other institutions will have large delegations
and Hopkins must be well represented. Information can be had from the General
Secretary, or from any member of the committee. Circulars are on the Secretary's desk in Levering Hall. This is the best possible opportunity to get acquainted with men of other institutions. The whole life and tone of the c'imp and
conference is very high and calls out the best there is in a man.

THE NEWS LETTER.

15

Prof. H. 14. Wilson, as president of our Association, attended the conference
of Presidents of College Associations for the East, at Harvard, April 16-18.
Ninety delegates from forty-four institutions of New England, New York, New
Jersey and Maryland, and the professional schools of Philadelphia were present.
Mr. L. S. Morgan represented Hopkins Medical School Association. Very profitable and interesting sessions were held. Dr. Alexander McKenzie addressed
the closing meeting on Sunday evening and deepened the impression made by
the rest of the conference of the absolute necessity for "a life hid with Christ in
God," if the men are to represent their Master among their fellow-students.

THE SEEKER.
A traveler journeyed o'er the hills,
Seeking, seeking ever;
Through the valleys, cross the hills,
Resting never, never.
"Oh weary man what urges thee?
Pause and rest awhile."
"Nay," he said, "it cannot be,"
With a wistful smile.
"Oh restless rover, seekest thou
Some cherished ideal?
lluck it from thy heart and brow
Now before the real."
"Nay, nay," he sadly shook his head,
liast'ning with the day,
"I must ever seek," he said,
"O'er the hills away."

A TREATISE ON THE COW-PUNCHER.
He is likely idle,
ex), I NITER is an empty season to the "cow-puncher.
though there is a chance that, as one out of twenty, he is retained to
"ride fence" or " ride bog holes," in the first case to patrol the barbwire and repair gaps that might allow flow from one pasture to another, and in
the second to haul forth from at least one certainty of death the many weakened
cattle that get mired. For the ranch-owner winter is such a hazard that he would
hold his breath through it if the period of danger were a trifle shorter. Ravens
Prospect about the prairie ; there are raw skins hung on the fences; and rumors
come from further on the plains that the "I.Ialf-circle W's- have lost two thousand head.
The popular •mood lightens when Spring comes in, nimbly as always ; and,
after a thorough rain with predictions that "there'll be grass in two weeks," the
men begin to gather to the ranch headquarters. They are perhaps a fortnight
ahead of the least move to work, yet they are welcome to unroll their bedding in
the "dive," to eat of the.beef and stewed prunes in the "chuck-house," and so to
wait till what time they may be taken under wages again.
Among them are many "sweaters," — crude boys, on a first essay, whose
capital in life is the remnants of a saddle and a willingness to ride bronchos.
ri;very one waits in ignorance, because the manager is as a rule hostile to inquiries,
hut at last a dav is realized on which the punchers of last year get their places
anew and perhaps tionie of the "sweaters" cast off that name ; and on the next
morning the "outfit" starts for the pasture ;—a line of horsemen, followed cumbrously by a wagon piled high with bedding and tooled by the cook.
On the Stirrup Ranch as on others, the horses are to be got first,—the three
or four hundred animals turned out for the winter,—and to that end the outfit,
after a while of slow travel, makes camp upon the mesquite-covered prairie at the
foot of the great steppe that is the Plains. The gather is accomplished in sections, and each day possesses the same round of active work. In the early hours
the view is quiet as the men scatter to their places in a loose circle that may hold
within it thirty square miles ; then all about in the green of the mesquite one sees
far off brown and white motes in mid-career with a variegated speck close behind and a second, swift as a centaur, closing in from another quarter; then
the motes resolve themselves into horses and the specks into mounted men ; and
Perhaps ten minutes after the ground in front of one is full of the tiinnilt of hoofs
and of pursuers and pursued until it settles with a restive bunch of horses and
pickets round about you. The cow-boys take fresh mounts from those cap-

tured ; and as they' rope for some particular head among so many it is not unusual
. favorite of last year,---'A1 Bald" it may be or "Diamond
that they miss the
joe,"—and catch a bronch' which four men at the end of the rope must strain
to hold till the running noose has "choked him down." Old favorites too rebel
at first of the saddle, and it is under such circumstances that high art in "bucking"
is most evident, with the rider in that contorted bend which the stranger never
understands to be involuntary till he himself has been "busted" by a broncho.
A proportion of the horses ignore the gregarious instinct and make escape to be
outlaws ; yet after a week the outfit can return to the ranch-house with a docile
quarter of a mile of horses driven before.
At the ranch there is a stir with friction over the choice of mounts. Each
man has the dozen that served him last year yet wishes as many more ; and
discussion of hocks and withers and stifle-joints is hot, until with the allotment
under charge of the "horse-wrangler" the outfit puts forth afresh, this time to
work with the cattle.
The grass rises ankle-deep by now on the Stirrup lands, and even where the
prairie-soil shows through are great white and lemon primroses and mats of
purple verbena. What part of the pasture lies on the Plains has still a rather
hare sward ; and when one ascends the "Cap-Rock,"—a hundred feet of rough,
colored slope, which like the moraine to a glacier, is an abrupt border along the
foot of the wide-spread plateau,--.--one finds an expanse of earth and sky, elementary as an ocean view, but with a somber fixedness that the ocean has not,
with perhaps an uneasy antelope or two in the distance, a wire fence that goes
rapidly off into perspective, and quivering lines of heat that for some reason
magnify the far-off herd grotesquely and give its members unsteady, stilt-like legs.
Each morning the outfit makes a drive that ends in a round-up. The drive,
though slower, is of a plan with that for horses. 1 ly the time the sun has got
to its strength the cattle have been started from the grazing and appear in troops
that center on an open level in the mesquites. If the drive be large a van-guard
of baby calves will clog proceedings, and some must he carried over the pommel
of the saddle, and some stirred with the foot, when they flop down and relapse
instantly into sleep, as they will in spite of circumstances that should cause them
anxiety, and some even be left with a mother to stand over them. Before noon
a couple of acres of cattle are assembled ; a couple of acres of tossed horns and
crowded brown backs ; a couple of acres that bleat and bawl like a brass band
in its preliminaries ; and that eddy ,round and round. The men change horses,—
they are always changing horses at the least moment of rest,—and the more
arduous "cutting out" begins, to obtain the yearlings at this season. It is very
like polo:—dust, with horses that dodge in the midst of the dust, only in this instance instead of the ball, a yearling, fond of his parent, is to be separated from
her, and out of the press and coerced to the bunch of his fellows a hundred yards
off. As time goes the cattle circle more restlessly and are harder to "hold," the
dust rises and blows, and the bellowing and moos become loudly incessant ; until
second outfit interlocks with that so far
the final yearling is "chousted out.
followed, with which the yearlings must go perforce off to exile till they arc

weaned; so labor for the first gang has its finish for the day. There is a steeplechav to where dinner waits with the wagon at sonic near-by tank of water.
hater comes a move to fresh territory, but always an hour or two is on hand at
the cool end of the afternoon, through which one can wash saddle-blankets or
bridle a "quirt," lie in laziness, or,—if conditions ask for it,—stretch "tepees"
against the rain.
Thus till the fall, even till December, cow-boys punch cattle. (hi the Stirnip's land, with its 40,000 head, work exists till late. In Spring the yearlings
must be weaned, then the brand is put on calves,—breathless business it is for
the fellow who must wind arms about fifty in succession as they bound at the
end of the rope, and throw them (breathless too, for the calves),—and at all
times special grades are to be separated for market. Through these processes
runs the organization into herd and round-up and cut. "Stray men" are sent
with a string of horses and a pack of quilts to follow the round-ups of the
"Lazy L's "( ) nearby and claim property that has got past the barb-wire;
and sometimes sonic one is called upon to find a trail to the rail-road,—for now
what with fences a herd may not be brought straight by compass. Once or
twice a season the outfit must "go on the trail," when, indeed, it pays for idleness
with a routine which insists that each man shall herd and press on while it is
light and stand a watch in the darkness, and even guard through the night if the
cattle are anxious. Year-long convoys from Texas to Montana or even lower
Canada, without help of the railroad, are undertaken, but conditions against these
gain in. stringency.
The cow-boy draws from $25 to $-10 each month for his irregular performance, whereas a farm-hand of the same region bends his back so long as
he is awake, yet may not expect more than $16 in a similar length of time ; that
shows nearly the ratio of skill in the employments. Skill insures life in the cowboy's case as more spectacularly in the steeple-jack's. The cow-boy is often
under discomfort, of weather, of lone vigil, of isolation ; his future is unstable,
except in most cases for a certainty that he will be laid off without wages during
the bitter stretch of the year. Altogether one cannot judge him overpaid.
The type of man may almost be deduced from the conditions given,—had
it not been often depicted with more gusto than discretion. Young blood finds
the life good and in many instances grows to be old blood while the charm of it
still hangs in the veins. One sees many middle-aged and stout cow-boys. Change
has broken not a few traits of the country ; the six-shooter is no longer a habit,
under the fines that now hedge about its possession ; and shortly as time goes, the
great free-handed ranches will disintegrate into small careful stock-farms. The
old-timers, lavish in their dealings with the world, find in each year a load of
disappointment, but a reasonable half of the punchers, hacked by youth and
steadied by ambition, have an eve to their doubtful prospects, and are at earnest
to make a "stake" in cattle. Indeed nowadays the "Great Staked Plains," as a

THE AMERICAN STATE.
F,DrrED

BY PROFESSOR W. W.

wILLouGit By.

The Century Company, of New York, is to publish a series of volumes under
the general title Of "The American State," which is to be edited by Dr. W. W.
Willoughby, Associate Professor of Political Science. The aim of the series is
to describe comprehensively the manner in which the governmental agencies of
the American State, Federal, Commonwealth, and Local are now organized and
administered. While the volumes shall be descriptive of actual conditions, incidentally they will aim to suggest the various constitutional and administrative
problems that exist, and make manifest the essential considerations involved in
their settlement.
The series will consist of eight volumes, as follows: The American Constitutional System; American Legislatures and Legislative M ethods ; The American
Executive and Executive Methods ; TheAmerican Judicial System ; Territories
and Colonies ; Local Government in the United States ; City Government in the
United States; and Political Party Machinery.
It will be observed, that as distinguished from many so-called "series" or
"libraries," this set of volumes will constitute a logical wbole, that is, will be encyclopedic as regards the special field covered. Each volume, though complete
in itself will have its proper place with special reference to that fact.
The first volume of the series, "The American Constitutional System," the
aim of which will be to furnish a general introduction to a study of the constitutional system of the American State, is to be prepared by Dr. Willoughby, who
expects to publish his book before the end of the year. Four of the remaining
volumes have already been provided for, and the editor hopes to have the entire
series published by the end of 1904.

NEW EDITOR OF JUVENAL.
The edition of the satires of Juvenal, upon which Dr. H. L. Wilson has
been at work for several years, is to be issued from the press early in June.
The book will consist of about 400 pages, and will contain a discussion of
Roman satire, the life of Juvenal, Juverial's style and place in literature, a history
of the text and a bibliography. Besides this there will be a complete text of the
author, including the recently discovered Bodleian fragments, the commentaries
and the index.
The book is not only intended for undergraduate students, but also offers to
teachers and advanced students assistance for a more thorough study of the satires
and information as to the progress made in the interpretation of this author
during the past ten years,

THE HULLABALOO CLUB FEED.
ATURDAY night last, a feed was given in the Trophy Room by the "Hullabaloo" Club to the Junior Class. The occasion was celebrated by several impromptu "'stunts" in the cage, the most interesting being hurdle
races, participated in by self-constituted sprinters, who, though more or less
stained by their race, were overshadowed by another and blacker race, two
chocolate representatives who indulged in a boxing bout. Jim "also ran" upon
the scene to play the rubber, aml with a towel, circumscribed the dark circles
under the eyes of the sluggers and smoothed their newly evoked facial ripples.
Thus seeing the race problem summarily disposed of, both classes retired
to the Trophy Room, where they regaled themselves with tempting edibles,
liquidating their debts to the inner man with time draughts on their own high
spirits.
Secretary Addison announced from the bench that the following men had
been selected to compose the Board of Governors of the Club for the ensuing
year: Messrs. Fuerbring-er, Erlanger, Stollenwerck, ll'earre, Buckler, Wayson,
Hawkins, Louis, Branch and Foster.
The Hullabaloo Club was organized by the Class of 1903 for the purpose
of promoting good-fellowship among its members. Its constitution, if conscientiously adhered to, will no doubt be the means of bringing the men closer together socially, and will do much towards fostering good will and disproving
the no college life idea at Hopkins.
The object of the organizers of the Club was to eliminate all politics from
it, there being no presidential office to be filled, the supervision of the business
details being vested in the Baord, assisted hy a Secretary and a Treasurer.
If the requite amount of interest to render the organization successful is
shown, the Board of Governors may decide to ask the lower classes to identify
themselves with the Club, and thus make it an undergraduate and not a class
organization.
The Seniors are invited to attend the Field Night to be given by the Hopkins Club on Saturday, May 1,3rd. Dr. Welch will give a short talk, and refreshments will be served later.
On last Thursday, the class in Minor Botany, under the charge of Dr. Barton and I\1 r. Gudger, took a trip to Mt. Washington for the purpose of studying
the flora.
The University musical clubs made their last appearance of the year at the
concert for the benefit of the Lawrence House Mission, given in conjunction with
the Woman's College Musical Clubs on the night of May 9th. The attendance
was large, and a considerable sum was turned over to the mission.
A committee from the Junior Class is making arrangements for a feed and a
smoker at the close of the examinations.
The minor geology class made a trip to the Luray Caves last week under the
charge of Dr. Shattuck. They left Friday afternoon and returned Sundav morning. Those who went were Nelson, Winternitz, Riley and Bamberger.

HE number of books that are being published by University men is worthy
of more than passing notice. Scarcely an issue of ME NEWS-LETTER
appears that does not contain an account of new books by Hopkins professors or alumni. This number conains two important announcements, one of the
new edition of Juvenal, by Dr. Harry L. Wilson, and the other of the series, The
American State, which is to be edited by Dr. W. W. Willoughby. Some time ago
Tliv, NEws-LnuR contained a note to the effect that Prof. Wilson was preparing
a new edition of Juvenal, but nothing definite was stated. Now, however, we are
able to speak more of this book, which has been eagerly awaited by scholars, and
which bids fair to fulfil all that is expected of it. We are informed by competent
authority that Dr. Wilson's work is the most thorough edition of the Latin
Satirist ever published in this country, and will probably at once become the
authority. The series of the American State, to be edited by Dr. Willoughby,
will be one of the most important contributions to Political Science that has been
issued for some time. While all the volumes have not yet been assigned to
writers, it is probably that a majority of them will be written by Hopkins men,
since the part they have taken in advanced economic work is great. The publication of these books indicates that the spirit of creative intellectuality at the 'University is as vigorous as ever.

HE 1903 "Hullabaloo," of which the first edition, so to speak, was issued
. last Monday, is, in many respects, the best year-book which has been
brought out since the introduction of this time-honored custom of Hopkins
undergraduate life. The approval shown by every one who has bought a copy is
the best proof of the fact that the book is up to the expectations of the most
critical. The neatness and fullness of the book, and the almost total absence of
the ordinary typographical errors, indicate the long and careful work of a comtetent board of editors.
The features which seem to arouse the most interest and cause the most
laughter, are the "stunts" and the "grinds" on members of the Senior class. The
"Hullabaloo Intelligence Office" could not be improved upon. The virtues and
vices of each man are taken off in an extremely outspoken way. The class
opinions are original, interesting and comprehensive. The result of the class vote
on the handsomest man doubtless caused much sorrow.
The pictures are excellent. The color drawing is particularly dainty and
They,
attractive. The drawings by prominent artists speak for themselves.
however, have the disadvantage that the .woman experienced when she carried a
new Venus de Milo into her slightly shabby parlor. Everything else looked
small in comparison, even things which, not subjected to such invidious parallels,
would stand well on their own smaller merits in their own smaller way. This
gives the book a species of unevenness, which, however, easily gives away to
fascination when we take any detail by itself.
The various departments of the l Tniversity are arranged in a pleasing and
thorough manner, particularly "\thletics. The "Songs of johns Hopkins" are
also a good point about the book.
In conclusion, the following criticism might, perhaps, be made. The 1903
"Hullabaloo" is hardly, as the editors jokingly claim, "truly representative of
the l'niversity," as it has to do wholly with the Senior class. We venture this
less as a criticism than as a suggestion to future "Hullabaloos."

'94 Robert A. Dobbin was married on Thursday, \pril 30th, to Miss Marie
Kerr Hemsley.

Among the undergraduates who are going abroad this summer, are Bevan
and Plaggemeyer, '03, who will sail from New York on the 13th of next month.
They will spend several weeks in Italy, after which they will travel through Europe, not neglecting to visit Monte Carlo and Paris. The latter part of August
and September will be passed at Oxford, where they will take a special course in
Social Economics. Strauss, '03, and Erlanger, 'Oh, leave on June 11th, for a
three months' trip, during which time they will "do" the Continent generally. R.
Curzon Hoffman, jr., '03, will depart from New York for an European trip, on
Wednesday, June 10th. He will be absent three or four months, which time will

LACROSSE.

J. H. U., 3—Crescents, 10.
0N May 9th, before several thousand spectators, the Hopkins lacrosse team
suffered its first defeat of the season in the game against the Crescent
Athletic Club, of Brooklyn, the score being 10 to 3. The ,game was one
of the nu.)st scientific exhibitions of lacrosse ever seen in Baltimore ; but most of
the science was on the side of the visitors. The 'Varsity did not seem to play up
to its usual standard, for its work appeared tame in comparison with that of its
opponents, who played the real Canadian game. It was not poor playing, however, that lost for the 1.Tniversity, but superior playing by the Crescents. In
every point of the game Hopkins was clearly outclassed. The weight of the
Crescent players averaged far more than that of the Hopkins men, and their
body checking was in consequence something terrible.
The passing of the
champions was faultless, and it was only through the fastest kind of work on
the part of the defense that plays were broken up. The defeat, however, is by
no means an inglorious one, for the victors are all star players. They are the
pick of some of the best teams in the country, and have been playing lacrosse
for years; therefore it was expected that they would be victorious over the 'Varsity.
Hopkins defense certainly played a fine article of lacrosse at times, and if
they could have struck their gait sooner, the Crescents could not have rolled up
ten goals. The body checking of Tough was very effective all through the game
in breaking up plays, and from the latter part of the first half to the close of the
game, Bland( also brought in his weight for some splendid work. On the Hopkins attack, Abercrombie did by far the best work. This is the first game in
which he has been allowed to play during this year, owing to the four-year-limit
rule, and the great player •hears comparison with any on either team. If the
other attack men had some of the confidence with which he plays, Hopkins would
have made more goals.
Hopkins got the ball at the start, and passed it down toward the net. Near
the posts Liffton obtained the ball, then passed it to Simpson, who threw to
Curry, who in turn had almost a clear field, as the defense was too late in covering up, and he threw the first goal within a minute from the time the game
commenced. Again the ball went rapidly down to Hopkins territory, and an

THE NEWS LETTER..
attempt was made at goal, but Schmeisser blocked it with his body. In the scrimmage that followed, Lindsay obtained the ball and shot the second goal. Within
the next twenty minutes some fine playing was seen. The 'Varsity had apparently recovered from its nervous spell and now settled down to business. The
ball was passed to Curry, who made a pretty run through his opponents right
up to the post. Just as he was about to shoot, Blanck struck him with his body,
and knocked the ball out of his stick. The ball was thrown down the field to
Rosenheim, who passed to Bird, and by Bird to Matthai. Matthai threw it to
Putts, who attempted goal. Everyone thought a goal was sure, but their hopes
were dashed to the ground when Dr. Rose made a fine stop. For some time the
ball was kept near the Crescents' goal. The•game was now on in earnest. Hopkins worked hard to put the sphere between the posts, and several attempts were
made. The ball passed from side to side. Several times P. Straus was called
upon to make difficult stops, and each, time he was right there.
It was during this playing that the Hopkins players scored their first goal.
Bird got the ball and passed to Rosenheim, who threw to liernheini. Beruheim
dodged his opponents and placed the ball in the net. About three minutes later
Crescent increased her lead to three. After some more see-saw playing, the
half ended with the ball near Hopkins' goal.
In the first part of the second half, Crescent took Hopkins' nerve completely,
by making six goals, each about two minutes apart. After this the locals commenced to cover up more, and the result was a decided brace. From the time
Crescent made her ninth goal to the close, Hopkins played by far the best of
any time during the game. The whole attack got together and kept the ball most
of the time in Crescent territory. Such playing could not fail to bring its reward, and Hopkins scored two more goals to Crescent's one. The game ended
with the ball in the middle of the field.
The Hopkins line-up was: Putts, in-home ; Bernheim, out-home ; Rosenheim,
first attack ; Abercrombie, second attack ; Bird, third attack ; Matthai, center ;
Tough, third defense ; Custis, second defense ; H. Straus, (captain) first defense ;
Ilanck, cover point ; Schmeisser, point ; P. Straus, goal.

DUAL MEET WITH VIRGINIA.

Ill-i', season of the track and field team practically closed on Thursday, May
7th, when in the presence of a large crowd of faithful rooters, the Hopkins squad gained a decided victory over the athletes from the University
of Virginia. This meet made a sort of "garrison" finish, forming a fitting climax
to a successful season's work. In the eleven events, Hopkins won 8 firsts and
5 seconds, thus getting 55 points, as against the 33 of Virginia. It looked at first
as if everything was coming our way, but later Virginia got together and suc-

t

THE NEWS LETTER.

13

ceeded in making their presence felt. Disregarding results as shown by the summary,. the visitors need feel in no way dissatisfied with their performance; it was
simply a case of "when Greek meets Greek," in which Hopkins proved to be the
better Gre,ek ; a .case of a good man losing to a better one in a hard struggle.
Aside from this meet being peculiarly satisfactory to Hopkins enthusiasts,
it was of much interest from a purely athletic point of view, in that State records
were broken so often that the novelty of it was beginning to wear off. First
individual honors were carried off by H. K. Tootle, who won both the 100 yard
and the 220 yard dashes, in each case lowering the State records of 10 1-5 and
23 seconds respectively, by covering the distances in 10 and 22 flat. The world's
records are 9 3-5 seconds for the 100 yards, held by Arthur F. Duffy, and 21 1-5
seconds for the 220 yards, held by B. J. Wefers. J. A. Freese established records
for the 120 yard high hurdle and 220 yard low hurdle, his time being 17 2-5 and
27 seconds respectively. In the quarter mile run, Captain Shelton, of Virginia,
lowered the State record of 51 2-5 seconds, formerly held by England, to 51 1-5
seconds. Besides these, the pole vault was won quite handily by T. W. Emig,
who, although entered before in several indoor events, had never specially distinguished himself. His victory came quite as a welcome surprise, and shows talent
that has previously been too little regarded. After winning with a jump of 9
feet, 11 1-4 inches, Emig endeavored to break the State record of 10 feet, 1 inch,
and (lid successfully clear the bar at 10 feet, 2 1-1 inches, but his pole afterward
knocked the bar down.
The good work for Hopkins began with the 1.00 yard dash and continued with
few interruptions until the end. All four (lashes were hotly contested, but ,Hopkins won out in each, through the instrumentality of Tootle and Freese. In the
1,10 yard run, Shelton and Bass, of Virginia, had the lead till near the finish.
when Captain Hoffman, by a beautiful sprint, passed Bass and ended in second
place. The surprise of the afternoon, however, came in the mile run. Grant,
of Virginia, gave out about. GOO yards from the tape, while Tyree lacked about
half that distance of finishing. The race then narrowed down to the two freshmen, Morse and ,Campbell, was a contest to decide to whom the "H" was to be
awarded. With not more than a foot separating them, Morse crossed the tape in
the lead. Hopkins clearly showed her superority in the dashes and in the long
distance run of one •mile, but had to give the palm to Virginia for the distances
of 440 and 880 yards. The summary of events was as follows:

Y. M. C. A. NOTES

The Association at the University of Illinois has been doing- splendid work
this )'ear. They have had 355 men enrolled in voluntary Bible Classes, and a
band of 21 volunteers for Foreign Missionary service, of whom 12 have been enrolled since the close of last college year.
The May Intercollegian publishes an interesting list of names of 211 student
volunteers who have sailed for Foreign Missionary work since March, 1902.
It is interesting to note that the largest number is to China, where they are needed
to take the places of those killed during the Boxer uprising.
The prospect for a strong and interesting conference at Northfield this summer, June 20th to July 5th, is very good. The names and number of speakers
is very strong and one of the latest additions is that of Rev. R. j. Campbell, of
the City Temple, London, England. One promised improvement in camp is a
"rustic lodge," with reading room. Other institutions will have large delegations
and Hopkins must be well represented. Information can be had from the General
Secretary, or from any member of the committee. Circulars are on the Secretary's desk in Levering Hall. This is the best possible opportunity to get acquainted with men of other institutions. The whole life and tone of the c'imp and
conference is very high and calls out the best there is in a man.

Prof. H. 14. Wilson, as president of our Association, attended the conference
of Presidents of College Associations for the East, at Harvard, April 16-18.
Ninety delegates from forty-four institutions of New England, New York, New
Jersey and Maryland, and the professional schools of Philadelphia were present.
Mr. L. S. Morgan represented Hopkins Medical School Association. Very profitable and interesting sessions were held. Dr. Alexander McKenzie addressed
the closing meeting on Sunday evening and deepened the impression made by
the rest of the conference of the absolute necessity for "a life hid with Christ in
God," if the men are to represent their Master among their fellow-students.

THE SEEKER.
A traveler journeyed o'er the hills,
Seeking, seeking ever;
Through the valleys, cross the hills,
Resting never, never.
"Oh weary man what urges thee?
Pause and rest awhile."
"Nay," he said, "it cannot be,"
With a wistful smile.
"Oh restless rover, seekest thou
Some cherished ideal?
lluck it from thy heart and brow
Now before the real."
"Nay, nay," he sadly shook his head,
liast'ning with the day,
"I must ever seek," he said,
"O'er the hills away."
